text: I'd like to go to 2006, 2017, and 2022, if you don't mind. The floor is yours. Oh, thanks. Well, I appreciate that. 2006, the banks were still mega players. And 2006 was a big volatility suppression year too. The banks, from my experience, always had the viewpoint that they would ride the horse until the horse fell over. So if the horse was making money for them, or if something was working, they would just keep doing it. They knew that their downside individually was bounded, and their upside was big. So you get a lot of long in the two things that would eventually unravel. 2017 was somewhat similar, but probably less bank driven. There was artificial suppression of volatility. But I think by that point, there was the realization, it takes a long time for us to realize these things, that interest rates probably weren't coming back up soon. Of course, the realization was earlier than that, but it was clear at that point. And so people were desperately, looking for proxies for carry. Japan has been ahead of the curve in all of this, certainly. And you know, the carry trade is bigger in Asia, in many ways, in Korea and Japan, than it is in the US. But various people wanted to substitute carry, or alternative forms of carry, for yield, classical treasury-based yield. And that caused volatility to be trading at incredibly low levels. Now, it's hard to manage. On the one hand, it's easy to manage such a book. You just go out and you warehouse. Cheap of all, and you put it in the cupboard, and you don't look at it, and you do other things. You don't micromanage your portfolio. You just put it in there. And whatever you do for the rest of your investing, you do that. But you don't try nickel and dime at the margins, because you've got all this cheap convexity embedded in your book, which allows you to take risk everywhere else. And of course, eventually that blew up. People made a huge amount of money in February 2018. I was actually not one of them, because I was moving from one gig to another, So sad to say I wasn't the beneficiary of the thing that I'm somewhat known to have talked about, but so be it. But that blew up. And so there were lots of opportunities that market tremors was trying to indicate where there was a zombification of markets. And I was pushing hard to get the book out because I knew that the cycle could turn, but I should have pushed harder. I didn't think it would turn when it did. And now that brings us to 2022. I think a good lead up to 2022 was December of 2021, where the VIX was pretty high. And more to the point, S&P options across various tenors were quite expensive. Implied volatility was high. In fact, until today, I don't think it's much higher now than it was for a fixed term than it was at the close of yesterday. It might be about the same. That caused a huge problem for the tail risk community. Now, I have never defined tail risk because I don't know exactly. What it is. I don't know what a benchmark is, but I do define hedging as being a number of things in a number of markets. But if I had to pick one market, let's say the S&P, it's a combination for me of three things. Gamma hedging at the short end, spread trading for middle maturities, let's say three to six months where other people like to buy insurance and Vega plays or interest rates slash Vega plays going out a year or more. So I break the book up into those pieces. And as you point out, 2022 has been quite different because the standard tail risk idea, which is to lock and load, let's say 20% or 25% out of the money put hasn't worked. Haven't checked my screen recently, but I'm not concerned about that specifically. Why hasn't it worked? Because volatility didn't go up enough from where it was. And you also faced a headwind where if vol goes from 10 to 20, you make a heck of a lot more than if it goes up. It goes from 30 to 45 because you can just buy that many more units of protection. You can buy that many more contracts when vol is low. So if you have a fixed budget, you can really go to town. If volatility is low, you have to be much more conservative if it's higher. And so that's been one problem. The other one is that the market has gone down, at least up to now, in a trend worthy, semi slow way, which points to the idea that just this idea of value buying of volatility. And waiting for the big one doesn't always work. The evangelism of tail risk, which I have been somewhat involved in, but nowhere nearly as much as Nassim Taleb and various others, Spitznagel and others probably has changed the nature of the game a bit. The tails are the true tails are pretty thin. They're not actively traded. And you could argue that they're underpriced. We could debate this over a beer one day, but I've always said that they're on price. And buying the tails is just a way to keep in the game. You're almost there. Price indifferent up to a point as to what the cost of a one month, 30% out of the money put might be. Of course, if the VIX is at 70, maybe you care then, but otherwise generally not. And you try and do all the stuff in between. And so classical tail risk hedging, which, again, I haven't defined because I don't know exactly what it is. Static buying of puts from a value perspective or even mechanical buying of puts hasn't worked. And a lot of people who bought long vol have been confused. They're not really convinced about this. But as you and I know, that's one good reason to mix trend and vol. They are nice partners. They're nice partners in crime because trend doesn't require a repricing of risk. It just requires moves of big enough magnitude. Vol doesn't require necessarily big moves, but if something comes out of the blue that changes the perception of risk, it can be hugely, hugely beneficial.
